title: The Unexpected Face of Mercy
devotional:
Eliza had always been a rule-follower. Not just at work, but in life. She followed the speed limit to the mile, returned shopping carts to the corral without fail, and meticulously separated her recycling. She believed in order, in justice, in everyone getting what they deserved. So, when her neighbor, Mr. Henderson, started racking up parking tickets due to his ailing eyesight making it difficult to navigate his large sedan, Eliza felt a conflict brewing. He was breaking the rules, repeatedly. A sternly worded note seemed appropriate, a consequence for his actions. But then, she saw him struggling to get out of his car one afternoon, his face etched with pain as he clutched his back. He looked so frail, so utterly defeated. 

Eliza hesitated. The righteous indignation she’d been harboring faltered. Instead of leaving the note, she offered him a hand. Over the next few weeks, Eliza found herself helping Mr. Henderson with errands, driving him to appointments, and even navigating the bureaucratic maze of appealing his parking tickets. She discovered that behind the repeated infractions was a man grappling with the indignities of age, struggling to maintain his independence. Her black-and-white view softened, replaced by a growing sense of compassion. 

Mercy, she realized, wasn't about ignoring the rules, but about understanding the circumstances behind them. It was about choosing kindness over condemnation, empathy over enforcement. It was about extending grace to those who stumbled, recognizing that everyone, at some point, needs a helping hand. Eliza learned that true justice wasn't always about rigid adherence to the law, but about tempering it with mercy and understanding.
image_description: A close-up of hands clasped together, one older and wrinkled, the other younger and offering support. The background is softly blurred, suggesting a residential street with bare winter trees.
insights: Eliza's story illustrates a key tension between justice and mercy, a theme explored throughout Scripture. Micah 6:8 calls us to 'do justice, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with your God.' This verse doesn’t suggest choosing one over the other, but rather integrating them into our lives. Jesus exemplified this balance, upholding the law while consistently extending mercy to the marginalized and outcast. The parable of the Good Samaritan (Luke 10:25-37) is a powerful example of choosing mercy over adherence to social and religious norms.
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to the opportunities to extend mercy to those around me. Help me to see beyond the surface, to understand the struggles and circumstances that shape people's actions. Soften my heart towards those who err, and give me the courage to choose kindness over condemnation. Remind me that I, too, am in constant need of Your mercy, and may that awareness inspire me to be more compassionate and forgiving towards others. Amen.
reflection: Think about a situation in your life where you're tempted to judge someone harshly. What are the underlying circumstances you might be missing? How could you approach the situation with more mercy and understanding? How has God shown you mercy in your own life?
